data.title: Code - OSS dev does not start when I run npm run watch
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: code-oss-dev: 1.11.0
- OS Version: Mac Os 10.12.3 (16D32)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I forked the repo then followed the steps in the wiki [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute) And it worked. it launched when I ran npm run watch
2. I then saw their where changes so I ran ran git pull https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode.git master everything went fine I reinstalled and then ran npm run watch it ends with 
`[10:29:55] Finished compilation with 0 errors after 77029 ms`
`[10:30:00] [monaco.d.ts] Starting monaco.d.ts generation`
`[10:30:02] [monaco.d.ts] Finished monaco.d.ts generation`
But it does not launch. It hangs. I have had this running for 30 minutes. 

I am new to the code so if I am missing something simple Im sorry I am used to writing node.js backend in a team of 3.

data.title: "paused on debugger statement" instead of exception in the inspector
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: W10x64
- Node: 6.9.3

Launch config regarding console: 
```
"internalConsoleOptions": "neverOpen"
"console": "externalTerminal"
```

A simple case of trying to access property of ``undfined``:
![](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/105338698/ShareX/2017-03/Code_2017-03-03_16-54-35.png)

Error still passed to debug console:
![](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/105338698/ShareX/2017-03/Code_2017-03-03_17-11-42.png)

Shouldn't debugger just show the exception in the inspector on the left in the first place? In my case it just shows the normal local scope, as if it were a breakpoint stop

If I unwrap the lines, it shows that the break happens (at least visibly) one the line prior the one containing the problem:
![](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/105338698/ShareX/2017-03/Code_2017-03-03_17-13-39.png)
Regarding "debugger statement" - isn't it too vague?

If I step forward it gets thrown into the external console also, which is probably a correct behavior.
![](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/105338698/ShareX/2017-03/cmd_2017-03-03_17-17-57.png)

I don't know... some of it may be different issues, some are not even bugs (maybe I'm just used to node2 debugger). Also, it is probably related to #19750

thanx

data.title: Suggestion: configurationDefaults should be indicated in each language section

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
There's a recent section in the `settings.json` file for overwrite `editor` defaults for specific languages.
An specific and isolated section just for that.

```json
  "[go]": {
    "editor.insertSpaces": false
  },

  "[makefile]": {
    "editor.insertSpaces": false
  },

  "[markdown]": {
    "editor.wordWrap": "on",
    "editor.quickSuggestions": false
  },

  "[yaml]": {
    "editor.insertSpaces": true,
    "editor.tabSize": 2
  },
```

I think this is a bit counterintuitive.
If you want to change something specifically related to Markdown, the logic will make you to check the markdown section. Because you want to change some behaviour related to that kind of files. The same applies to the rest of languages. That was my case. I didn't knew about this specific overwritting and I went a little crazy when I updated my default editor config `editor.wordWrap` and it was working in all files... but markdown ones. So I quick checked the issues here and, eventually, I found in the code that there is an specific override for markdown files... in a section apart.

Even if you know about this section, it seems like a problem. Now, even if there isn't any overwritting at all for your specific language, you will need to check also that isolated section «just in case» there is something new overwritting anything that you aren't aware of.

Don't you think that having all the settings about a language in the language section is a better approach? As example, something like this, for the Markdown section:

```json
  "markdown.styles": [],
  "markdown.previewFrontMatter": "hide",
  "markdown.preview.fontFamily": "'Segoe WPC', 'Segoe UI', 'SFUIText-Light', 'HelveticaNeue-Light', sans-serif",
  "markdown.preview.fontSize": 14,
  "markdown.preview.lineHeight": 1.6,
  "markdown.preview.scrollPreviewWithEditorSelection": true,
  "markdown.preview.markEditorSelection": true,
  "markdown.preview.scrollEditorWithPreview": true,
  "markdown.preview.doubleClickToSwitchToEditor": true,
  ...
  "[markdown]": {
    "editor.wordWrap": "on",
    "editor.quickSuggestions": false
  },
```

**Note**: comments omitted for the sake of brevity.

data.title: Outline matching selections instead of highlight

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Highlight a selection with multiple instances. 
2. Look how hard it is to distinguish which instance is selected.

![screen shot 2017-03-03 at 7 33 55 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10407384/23555115/e1ab96e6-ffe4-11e6-9d82-687e859a8f26.png)
![screen shot 2017-03-03 at 7 36 55 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10407384/23555118/e38522ac-ffe4-11e6-968d-7913e65f2b49.png)

There are three fundamental issues that this request entails:

1. When you make a selection and there are multiple instances, it's extremely hard to distinguish which one is actually selected. This image shows VSCode's standard Monokai theme. This is not a "theme" issue, users should be able to use any theme that is available in the marketplace. 

2. When you make a selection, matching instances shouldn't be highlighted at all. Being highlighted indicates that they are also selected, which is not the case. So when I double click on a single word to select it, all the matching instances get highlighted too, creating the appearance that they are all selected.

3. The check that looks for matching instances should be _case sensitive_, so that when I select `contract`, a camel-case instance of `newContract` should not have that instance of contract highlighted.

data.title: CentOS: window.newWindowDimensions does not properly inherit the existing window

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: CentOS 7.3.1611

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open "User Settings" and confirm `"window.newWindowDimensions": "inherit"` is set.
2. In a non-maximized, non-fullscreen window, open a new window with `Ctrl+Shift+N`.
3. The new window is maximized and does not inherit the previous window dimensions.

Developer Tools output provides no error response in the console.

Additional info:

- The window setting worked as expected in 1.9.1 release.
- I had installed the previous version (1.9.1) via RPM download and upgraded to 1.10.1 via the new CentOS Yum repository. 
- GNOME is the active window manager.

    [14:27:23] [monaco.d.ts] Starting monaco.d.ts generation
    [14:27:23] [monaco.d.ts] WHILE HANDLING RULE:  #include(vs/base/common/cancellation): CancellationTokenSource, CancellationToken

    ...

And

    [14:27:56] Error: e:/Docs/Dev/vscode/src/vs/editor/common/standalone/standaloneBase.ts(221,3): Type '{ editor: undefined; languages: undefined; CancellationTokenSource: typeof CancellationTokenSourc...' is not assignable to type 'typeof monaco'.

    [14:27:56] Error: e:/Docs/Dev/vscode/src/vs/editor/browser/standalone/standaloneLanguages.ts(673,59): Property 'languages' does not exist on type 'typeof monaco'.

I did a fresh git pull and did not make any changes.

data.title: Toggled menu bar can make the entire window contents jump up making hit zones move

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Some mouse clicks are ignored when the menu bar is un-hidden (with Alt key).

- VSCode Version:
1.9.1, 1.10
- OS Version:
Windows 7 Enterprise, Windows 10 Pro

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Make sure the menu bar is hidden (View->Toggle Menu Bar)
2. Show the menu bar using Alt key
3. Select File->Preferences->Color Theme
Alt: File Icon Theme, or any menu item that will show an in-editor menu 
4. The Color Theme menu is shown
5. Left click on any theme

Expected result:
- Selected theme applied
- Menu dismissed
- Menu bar hidden

Actual result:
- The theme is not applied
- The menu is not dismissed
- The menu bar becomes hidden again.

Further steps:
6. Left click on any theme again
7. The theme is applied, the menu dismissed and the menu bar hidden, as expected.

data.title: reference number is missing from Source object

data.title: String DocumentFilter should only match scheme 'file' and 'untitled'

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.x

Document filters that are only string based should only match scheme file and untitled. So if an extension registers a feature provider for 'bat' for example the provider should only be invoked for 'file' and 'untitled' scheme and not for example for 'git' scheme.

data.title: Unexpected shift key bubbling

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Hold CMD
2. Hold SHIFT
3. Release CMD
4. Release SHIFT

In China many input methods use SHIFT key to switch between English and Chinese mode, however in vscode & macOS Sierra if we try "hold CMD -> hold SHIFT -> (press any other key) -> release CMD -> release SHIFT" system will detect a keypress event of SHIFT key and change the input mode, which is very annoying in coding job

I know this issue is related to webkit since google chrome has the exact same behavior, however vscode is deeply affected by it because there are many key combinations when coding, e.g. "CMD + SHIFT + LEFT" to select characters before cursor, this can randomly trigger the change of input mode, so is it possible this issue could be fixed in the scope of vscode?

data.title: Completion entries in package.json disappear when typing dot/period
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

I was adding some `configurationDefaults` to my `package.json`. I typed `"editor"` as shown here and got completion for all the different options. However when I press the dot, all of the completion options vanish, despite the dot being the next character in the completion items.

![Completion items vanish when typing dot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1078012/23548769/0200e3b2-0001-11e7-808d-5d2c6c5af868.png)

![Dot typed; completion items gone](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1078012/23548830/3ecf0c92-0001-11e7-8bb7-b919fd5104ab.png)

Pressing Ctrl+Space causes the list to reappear; but it seems like it shouldn't vanish (it doesn't when typing the other, non-dot characters).
